bibl.title: John Matthews v. Henry M. White. Correspondance
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington

body.p: INCLOSURE 3797
FROM DEPARTMENT OF LABOR, BUREAU OF IMMIGRATION
DIPLOMATIC REPRESENTATIVE OF GALACIA (WEST UKRAINIAN REPUBLIC) WASHINGTON, D.C.
File #125
September 13, 1921.
Mr. Leo B. Rusell, Bureau of Immigration, Department of Labor, Washington, D.C.
Dear Sir:
In accoradance with our telephone conversation, I have the honor to send you the following information:

Galacia or West Ukraine (generally called East Galicia) is a part of the former Austrian Monarchy. After the collapse of the Austrian Monrachy in 1918, the people of Galicia (East Galicia) organized themselves as an independent republic with their own perliament, government and army.

This West Ukrainian or Galician Republic is to be distinguished from the Republic of Ukraine, which was organized in the south of the former Russian Empire after the outbreak of the Russian Revolution in 1917. This Republic of Ukraine has its diplomatic mission of Washington since 1919. On the other hand, the Republic of Galicia (West Ukraine) sent its mission to the United States in 1921.

The government of the Galician Republic is now temporarily in exile outside the boundaries of this country because Galicia in 1919, after a bloody war which lasted for nine months between Galicia and Poland, was militarily occupied by Poland; but the Galician Government, the Great Allied Powers, and the League of Nations did not recognize the pretentions of Poland to this country. All these factors regard Galicia as a seperate entity of international law.

I take the liberty to mention that your Bureau of Immigration also was of this correct opinion when it pointed out East Galicia as a separate state in the list showing the annual number of immigrants permitted to enter the United States from every European country.
For further information of the Galician Republic, I beg to refer you to the enclosed statement, especially on pages 7 to 10 inclusive, where the international status of this country is discussed.

In reference to the passports, I wish to emphasize that the passports of our Republic in Vienna, Prague, Budapest, Berlin, Paris, London and Washington. All these representations, with the exception of the representation at Washington, are functioning since 1919 wihtout any interruptions.

Our mission in Washington was opened not only for diplomatic purposes but also for the needs of the natives of East Galicia of whom about 1,000,000 live in the United States and about 300,000 in Canada and who regard themselves as citizens of the Galician Republic.
If there is any other information you desire, please turn to us and we shall gladly furnish you with the same; we shall also be glad to serve you in all passport cases of natives of Galicia.

Very truly yours,
Diplomatic Representative of Galicia.
U.S. DEPARTMENT OF LABOR IMMIGRATION SERVICE DISTRICT NO. 16
IN REPLYING TO NO. 37012/600
DISTRICT HEADQUARTERS U.S. COMMISSIONER OF IMMIGRATION SEATTLE, WASH.
September 17, 1921
United States Attorney, Federal Building, Seattle, Washington:
(Attention Miss Kolmitz)
Sir:
In accordiance with your verbal request, I enclose herewith confirmation of the Department's telegram of the 13th instant, same having reference to the case of Jack Matthews.
Respectfully W Lynch Acting Commissioner
FILED IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT SEP 19 1921
F.M. HASHBERGER, CLERK By S.E. Leitch Deputy
